Elementary:

month in its biggest markets. In the last six
months, Facebook has lost nearly 9 million
monthly visitors in the US and 2 million in
the UK.

Elementary:
It has stopped growing in the US, UK and
other major European countries. In the last
month, the world’s largest social network lost
6 million US visitors, a 4% fall. In the UK, 1.4
million fewer users went on Facebook last
month, a fall of 4.5%.
Intermediate:
Studies suggest that its expansion in the
US, UK and other major European countries
has peaked. In the last month, the world’s
largest social network has lost 6m US
visitors, a 4% fall, according to analysis firm
Socialbakers. In the UK, 1.4m fewer users
visited in March, a fall of 4.5%.
Advanced:
As Facebook prepares to update investors
on its performance in the first three months
of the year, with analysts forecasting
revenues up 36% on last year, studies
suggest that its expansion in the US, UK and
other major European countries has peaked.

Elementary:
People are also using Facebook less in
Canada, Spain, France, Germany
and Japan.
Intermediate:
Users are also turning off in Canada,
Spain, France, Germany and Japan, where
Facebook is extremely popular.
Advanced:
In the last month, the world’s largest social
network has lost 6m US visitors, a 4% fall,
according to analysis firm Socialbakers.
In the UK, 1.4m fewer users checked in
in March, a fall of 4.5%. The declines are
sustained. In the last six months, Facebook
has lost nearly 9m monthly visitors in the US
and 2m in the UK.

Elementary:
“The problem is that, in the US and UK,
most people who want to join Facebook
have already done it,” said new media
specialist Ian Maude at Enders Analysis.
People get bored, he says, and they “like to
try something new”.
Intermediate:

Advanced:

Elementary:

popular with younger people. Instagram,
the photo-sharing site, got 30 million new
users in the 18 months before Facebook
bought the business.
Intermediate:

surges in popularity with younger people.
Instagram, the photo-sharing site, got

Advanced:

people who want to sign up for Facebook
have already done it,” said new media

to try something new. Is Facebook going to
go the way of MySpace? The risk is relatively
small, but that is not to say it isn’t there.”

Elementary:
Path, the mobile phone-based social
network started by ex-Facebook employee
Dave Morin, is gaining 1 million users a
week. It now has more than 9 million users.
500,000 Venezuelans downloaded the app
in just one weekend.
Intermediate:
Path, the mobile phone-based social
network founded by former Facebook
employee Dave Morin, which only allows
its users to have 150 friends, is gaining
1m users a week. It has recently topped
9m users, with 500,000 Venezuelans
downloading the app in a single weekend.
Advanced:
Alternative social networks such as
Instagram, the photo-sharing site that won
30m users in 18 months before Facebook
acquired the business, have seen surges in
popularity with younger age groups.

Elementary:

increased by 6% in the last month to 70
million, according to Socialbakers, whose
information is used by Facebook advertisers.
And there has been a 4% rise in India to
64 million users – still only a small part of
the country’s population, so there is the
possibility for more growth.

Elementary:

same as a year ago.

population, leaving room for

Elementary:
The number of minutes Americans spend on
Facebook is falling, too. The total was 121
billion minutes in December 2012, but that
fell to 115 billion minutes in February.
Intermediate:
Analysts at Jefferies bank saw global
numbers of visitors to Facebook peak at
1.05bn a month in January, before falling
by 20m in February. Numbers rose again in
April. The network has now lost nearly 2m
visitors in the UK since December, according
to research firm Nielsen, with its 27m total
the same as a year ago.
Advanced:
But in developed markets, other Facebook
trackers are reporting declines. Analysts at
Jefferies bank have developed an algorithm
that interfaces directly with Facebook
software and it “suggests user levels in [the
first quarter] may have declined from peak”.
